snippet.title: These businesses may escape Amazon's grip, Morgan Stanley says
snippet.content:
Almost nothing seems out of reach for Amazon these days. Grocery stocks crumbled in the US and here in Australia when the company bid for Whole Foods Market in June. Meal kit delivery startup Blue Apron slumped after Amazon got into prepared food kits. Sports chains slipped when Nike agreed to sell its wares on the e-commerce giant's website. But Amazon can't disrupt everything, at least according to Morgan Stanley.
Up Next
Woman gets jail sentence in texting-suicide case
01:24
More World News Videos
Previous slide Next slide
Amazon shifts focus to video streaming
The global shopping giant is expanding its reach into every aspect of retail, everything from e-books to groceries, but its biggest consumer spend has shifted to movies and television.
The firm's analysts, led by Brian Nowak, have researched what attributes make for an Amazon-proof industry and introduced a framework this week so investors can gauge how susceptible companies are to Amazon founder Jeff Bezos' corporate wanderlust. Here's a look at the five guidelines Morgan Stanley said are most important.
Uniqueness
The first hurdle is tailored items. The more unique an item is, the less likely it is to be at risk from Amazon. "Commodity products are more susceptible to Amazon disruption," the analysts wrote. "While unique and bespoke items are less likely to be purchased through Amazon's marketplace." Areas of travel such as hotels and vacation packages, formal apparel, and luxury goods are examples, they noted. Regulation
The more onerous a sector's rules are, the more costly it is and the bigger the payoff would have to be for Amazon to consider moving into the space, the Morgan Stanley analysts said. Health care, car manufacturing, financial services and telecom are examples, they added.
Heavy products
Products that are less profitable, less frequently ordered and heavier aren't as attractive to Amazon's main e-commerce business. So do-it-yourself auto parts, dollar stores, and home furnishings should be more immune to competition from the company, the analysts wrote. However, Amazon's recent deal to acquire Whole Foods shows the internet retailer is willing to take on tough product categories, they added.

Talking to customers
If there is a large amount of customer interaction required following the sale of an item, Morgan Stanley said Amazon is less likely to be interested. Those safest in this regard include health care, home improvement and specialty construction goods.Photo: AP Contract negotiations
The more time consuming the purchase is, the less likely Amazon is to want a piece of the action, the analysts wrote. One example: Large industrial contracts that can take months rather than days or weeks to negotiate. Sectors covered include pharmaceuticals, real estate and auto manufacturing. Bloomberg
